utterances: Yeah, they scrapped the meeting after the president of the Philippines, the newly elected president, Rodrigo Duterte, used a slur to threaten President Obama.
He was just elected a few months ago in a wave of populist fervor and on a promise to clean up drugs in the country.
So since his inauguration on June 30, more than 2,000 Filipinos have been rounded up and killed without due process.
In several cases, the people who have been victims here have just had the misfortune of being nearby, like a 5-year-old who was killed.
The White House said, heading into a possible meeting, that Obama would definitely bring up the human rights abuses inherent in extrajudicial killings.
And Rodrigo Duterte gave a press conference essentially lashing out.
(SOUNDBITE OF PRESS CONFERENCE)
I do not have any master except the Filipino people - nobody but nobody.
You must be respectful.
(Speaking Tagalog).

And what he said there in his native language of Tagalog is an obscenity about Obama's mother, followed by a quote; ""I will swear at you in front of everybody,"" a warning to President Obama that if he brought up these killings at their meeting, that's what would happen.
I think she's just really exciting to people.
She's very relatable and she seems to have kind of a very approachable sense of style.
And I think people feel that she wears pieces that they can actually afford sometimes.
She does a lot of mixing of high and low, she's been known to wear J.
Crew.
She wore a dress the designer White House Black Market which was like under $200.
So, I mean, she wears a lot of pieces that people can actually go out and afford, so there's a part of her that people feel is really accessible.
And you know.
Let's talk about, I'm sorry.
Well, let's talk about what she wore on the Inauguration Day.
She wore the outfits of a couple of relatively unknown designers, one of them Jason Wu who's only 26 years old, and Isabel Toledo.
Now, they were both on ""The Today Show"" yesterday.

And here's Isabel who designed that ginger grass, I'm told that's what it's called, although it kind of less sort of greenish yellow to me, an ensemble that Michelle wore on the inauguration proceedings.
Here's Isabel.
(Soundbite of interview on ""The Today Show"")
I've wanted a color that felt fresh.
I wanted a color that had optimism.
And I chose lace, in fact, this lace because also it's not a flat surface, it has all these depths.
So I thought it had more life.
So were you surprised by those selections that she wore?
I wasn't surprised that she chose designers that weren't as well-known.
But I was surprised that those were the designs that she picked.
I think that it's really refreshing and its pretty in line with what the Obamas represent, you know, as a couple and, you know why they want them, why people, love them so much, I think.
You know, it says a lot.
People would've expected Michelle to wear one of the big American designers like Calvin Klein or Donna Karan, Ralph Lauren, you know, kind of those big established brands.
Here's Jason Wu, for example, talking a little bit about the first lady and his design of the ivory-colored single strapped gown that she wore to the inauguration balls.
(Soundbite of interview on ""The Today Show"")
She's tall, she is beautiful.
And I wanted to design a gown that would highlight her best features.
And I wanted to say something about, who she is and what she - I see her as a powerful, energetic, incredible woman.
And you know why - you know, I want the gown to have a dream-like quality.
Now, you know, Marielle, everybody seems to be talking about that particular dress, don't they?
Yeah.
I think, again, it was very unexpected.
A lot of people don't - aren't familiar with Jason Wu.
He's a really young designer, he's only 26.
And I know she wore - she's worn a few of his pieces in the past but, you know, this really is going to put him on the map.
From a fashion standpoint, Marielle, was that dress a fashion hit or a fashion miss?
I think it was a fashion hit.
I think on television it was a little bit hard to see some of the detailing in the dress.
But it really had a lot of really intricate detailing.
It had some really beautiful embellishments with crystals.
And there were tons of tiny little rosettes and satin that were all over the dress.
And I think that the silhouette was really flattering on her, played up her arms which are her best assets, and I think the white was, you know, was really pretty on camera.
And I think she looked, you know, she looked like a goddess.

What impact do you think that she is going to make or perhaps, has already made regarding the way women dress and how they feel about their bodies especially since Mrs. Obama doesn't have what you might call a stick figure?
Yeah.
I think that Michelle really shows, you know, the average woman that.
You know, it's easy to find pieces that are flattering.
You know, it's just about knowing your body and knowing what works for your shape.
And her use of color, I think, is really encouraging.

A lot of women are afraid to wear color, but Michelle does a lot of fun things with color, where she'll mix brights and neutrals and all kinds of things, which a lot of women wouldn't think to do normally.
And what about dressing the girls, Sasha and Malia?
Sasha and Malia.
I think she does a great job with dressing them at the inauguration.
She had the girls wearing J.
Crew.
And it's interesting because I know she - the pieces were custom-made, the J.
Crew pieces that the girls wore, they had these coats that were in bright colors and matching dresses.
And the next day, the J.
Crew site had crashed because so many customers had gone online to try to purchase those pieces.
So it just really shows you how much, you know, people are really paying attention to what, not only Michelle is wearing but what the whole family is wearing including the little girls.
I'll put you on the spot a little bit.
From a fashion standpoint, Michelle Obama, on the scale of one to 10 is a?
I'd say she is a nine.
I think I'll put here like eight and a half, nine.

You know, there's always room to grow but I think what makes such a true fashionista is not always being, you know, crazy, daring and risk-taking, but I think it's really knowing what suits your body.
And I think she knows what works on her.
Marielle, thank you very much.
Thank you, it's a pleasure.
That was Marielle Bobo.
She is the senior fashion editor at OK!
Magazine.
This is News & Notes.
I'm Farai Chideya.
Going to your local polling station and casting a ballot should be simple, but what if you're no longer living in the neighborhood you're registered in.
For some people, that happens when they're deployed overseas by the military.
Others chose to move, of course, and yet more are displaced domestically by natural disasters like Hurricane Ike.
We're going to pick up our series on voting with a look at overseas and displaced voters.
Joining us now is Mark Sawyer.
He's an associate professor of political science at the University of California in Los Angeles.
Thanks for coming in the studios.
Thank you, Farai.
So, voting in the U.S.
can be complicated, but what's the process for voting in U.S.
elections but from overseas.
Go ahead.
You're on the line.

Are you Sam's members?
Yes.
But you're joining Mas?
Yes.
Why?

Why don't you just go to, like, Fiesta?
I don't care for Fiesta.
I don't like their prices.
I don't like the store setup either.

I like big stores.

Analysts say there may be some risks on taking a known commodity like a Sam's Club store and re-branding it for a niche market.
And it's much too early to tell if the Mas Club experiment will result in more Mas Club superstores.
But if it works, the company is eyeing another huge Hispanic market in Arizona.
Alex Avila, NPR News, Houston, Texas.
